time beekeeping (Sideliners) 
-
A source  of  additional  revenue 
in many developing countries

Commercial beekeeping 
-
Beekeepers derive a significant part of their income 
from bee
-
related activities.

Commercial beekeepers can generate income in 
several ways 
• 
Pollination services
: Farmers rent beehives to 
farmers. Hives are transported to different locations 
depending on the crop and season. 
• 
Honey production
: The honey is collected from the 
hives, processed, and then sold. 
• 
Bee byproducts
: beeswax, propolis, royal jelly, and bee 
pollen 
• 
Bee sales
:  breed and sell bees to other beekeepers, 
including queens. 
• 
Beekeeping supplies and education
:  manufacture and 
sell beekeeping 
equipment, or provide 
classes/consultations to novice beekeepers.

Management practices 
(Beekeeping “philosophies”) 
• 
Conventional 
• 
Natural/Darwinian 
• 
Organic

Typical Conventional Beekeeping includes: 
1.
Standard Beekeeping Equipment
: 
Langstroth hives 
2.
Use of Treatments
: to control pests 
and diseases within the hive, such as 
mites or fungal infections. Can include 
synthetic chemicals or medications. 
3.
Supplemental Feeding
: If 
necessary, provide supplemental 
feeding to the bees, typically sugar 
syrup or pollen substitutes 
4.
Swarm Control
:  actively manage 
their hives to prevent swarming,

Natural/Darwinian beekeeping 
• 
Allow bees to do their own beekeeping with minimal interference 
• 
Key features are 
1. 
Allowance of natural behaviors such as swarming 
2. 
Minimal Interventions: fewer hive inspections, and less 
supplemental feeding 
3. 
Natural treatment methods to control parasites and pathogens 
4. 
Use of locally adapted bees : local bees and queen adapted 
to local conditions 
5. 
Consideration of bees’ welfare 
More on how feral bees live: online lecture by 
Tom Seeley on November 20th

Organic beekeeping 
A form of Natural/Darwinian beekeeping that is particularly 
concerned with non
-
natural substances that bees might be 
exposed to, or that may end up in the honey they make.

Beekeeping in present

day Kenya 
Note that all subspecies of 
Apis 
mellifera 
in Kenya, 
even the 
monticola 
and 
litorea
, 
are very defensive

~80% of hives are log hives in Kenya 
(cheaper than Langstroth hives)

Those log hives are ingenious alternatives to 
using Langstroth frames

And they are typically suspended in trees 
as a defense against honey badgers

A more modern Kenyan hive model 
(though more expensive)  is 
a ONE box, trapezoidal, top bar hive
Top  bar  hives  are....

Those top bar hives are typically placed on top of 
wooden sticks

Beekeeping 
in present
-
day China

Chinese commercial beekeepers tend to use 
Apis 
mellifera 
and 
their beekeeping operation is typical of conventional beekeeping

Some 
Apis 
cerana 
colonies are kept in traditional log hives 
covered in mud and without removable frames

Other colonies are kept in 
wooden boxes that do not 
have removable frames

Cliffside hives in 
Shennongjia 
nature reserve, Hubei province

Most are kept in single boxes Langstroth hives, and they can 
then be spread out in a bamboo forest (Hubei province)

Or 
kept right next to houses because there are not as 
defensive as 
Apis 
mellifera

Why is 
Apis 
mellifera 
most often used for 
pollination services in agriculture. 
• 
Foragers invest time in learning about 
environment and adapt 
• 
Polyphagous yet Flower constancy 
• 
Honey bees are easier to manage and control 
• 
Honey bees are easier to transport 
• 
Honey bees are a superorganism, 
most wild 
bees’ survival based on 
individual level 
• 
Honey bees can be active year
-
round, 
most 
wild 
bees are only active for a short time 
• 
Honey bees’ ability to communicate and social 
cohesiveness enhances foraging behavior

800,000+ acres of almonds 
bloom every year in Central California 
• 
Almond varieties are self
-
incompatible 
• 
Each orchard is planted with two, typically 3, 
different 
varieties of almonds to allow cross
-
pollination 
• 
Bees needed to move the pollen from one variety to 
another 
• 
Need pollination services mid
-
February through 
mid
-
March

require 1.6 million colonies of 
honey bees
